Navigation
Name Tutorial
Synopsis This is a step-by-step by-example lesson plan to quickly learn programming in Rascal.
Details Basic Advanced Wizard
Description Rascal is a programming language for a particular domain: metaprogramming. First it is just a programming language. The lessons expect that you have some programming skill in another languages such as C, Java, PHP, Lisp, SmallTalk, Python, etc. Second it is for metaprogramming: designed to make common tasks in metaprogramming practical. You can learn it in three levels: Basic, Advanced and Wizard.

This tutorial does not have all there is to know about Rascal:
  • If you have not installed Rascal yet, now is the time because you will need to do this tutorial in the Eclipse IDE to get interactive questions: Rascal:InstallingAndRunning;
  • If you are looking for a specific problem you wish to solve, have a look at the Recipes course, which also explains some of the more popular libraries for Rascal;
  • If you wish to know the details about the syntax and semantics of Rascal language constructs, then the Rascal course is the reference manual.
  • If Rascal does not make sense on a conceptual level for you yet: have a look at the Rascalopedia.
The table of contents for this tutorial is:
  • Basic: What you need to know to do basic programming in Rascal
    • Values: What does the data look like that you can manipulate in Rascal and how to type it in?
    • IO: Basic input/output features of textual data and structured data
    • Expressions: How to compute in Rascal
    • Types: What to expect from the type system
    • Patterns: Pattern matching is a core language feature used in Functions, Statements, Expressions, Transformation, Query
    • Data:
    • Functions:
    • Statements: Structured control flow
    • Backtracking: Avoiding overly nested control flow structures using builtin backtracking mechanisms
    • Query:
    • Templates:
    • Transformation:
  • Advanced: Advanced programming tricks that make life better for writing and reading Rascal programs
    • DynamicDispatch:
    • TermRewriting:
    • HigherOrderFunctions:
    • ConcreteSyntax:
    • SyntaxDefinition:
  • Wizard: Rarely used but extremely powerful concepts for if you wish to start making your own libraries
    • CallingJava: Getting access to Java libraries from Rascal
    • CallingRascal: Getting access from Java to Rascal
    • IDEConstruction: Instantiate your own Eclipse plugin using a SyntaxDefinition and some library API
    • InterpretingReifiedTypes: Reusing abstract and concrete grammars for your own purposes
    • Resources: Generating new Rascal modules at compile-time to get typed access to external resources
